The  program  loan  will  support  implementation  of  the  Poverty 
Reduction  Program  outlined  under  the  multi-development  partner 
funded Poverty Reduction Support Credit III (PRSC III), as part of 
the  Government’s  overall  Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and 
Growth Strategy (CPRGS). 

Over the last decade the Government has quickly reduced poverty 
and achieved a high level of economic growth. Poverty reduction 
largely  resulted  from  economic  growth,  which  created  jobs  and 
provided  better 
livelihoods.  To  ensure  continuing  poverty 
reduction and economic growth, the Government needs to lock-in 
policy reforms, remove remaining structural weaknesses, promote 
socially  inclusive  development,  and  modernize  governance  and 
the public administration system.  

The CPRGS provides a framework  for poverty reduction policies, 
programs, and actions in Viet Nam, and has been adopted as the 
reference document by the official development assistance (ODA) 
for  planning  external  assistance.  Several  ODA 
community 
partners  including  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  support 
the  CPRGS.  The  CPRGS  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  poverty 
reduction  strategy;  and  its  country  strategy  and  program,  and 
poverty partnership agreement with Viet Nam.  
 
World  Bank  support  includes  three  PRSCs,  approved  in  2002 
(US$250  million),  2003  (US$100  million),  and  2004  (US$100 
million). The focus of these operations has gradually shifted from 
reform  of  state-owned  commercial  banks  and  the  state-owned 
enterprise  (SOE)  sector  to  a  broader  policy  agenda,  covering  a 
number  of  sectors  and  issues  affecting  poverty  reduction  and 
growth in Viet Nam.  

The  ODA  community  in  Viet  Nam  considers  the  PRSC  a  useful 
instrument for supporting CPRGS implementation. In 2004, major 
ODA partners such as Canada, Denmark, European Commission, 
Japan,  Netherlands,  and  United  Kingdom  are  cofinancing  the 
PRSC III with the World Bank.

Objectives and Scope 

ADB has been actively involved in formulating the PRSC III. ADB 
has  promoted  policy  dialogue  on  similar  issues  through  its 
program lending activities and sector policy reforms. The PRSC III 
complements ADB support to Viet Nam for policy and institutional 
reform.  As  a  multisector  instrument  covering  a  range  of  issues 
related  to  poverty  reduction,  the  PRSC  framework  provides  ADB 
with  an  opportunity  to  (i)  advance  and  widen  national  policy 
dialogue  in  a  well-coordinated  and  comprehensive  manner,  (ii) 
provide  lending  and  nonlending  assistance  in  coordination  with 
other  ODA  partners,  and  (iii)  ensure  key  policy  issues  important 
for  the  implementation  of  ADB  operations  in  Viet  Nam  are 
adequately  considered  and  addressed  in  the  policy  dialogue 
between the Government and the ODA community to help achieve 
the common goal of poverty reduction and growth. 

The  proposed  program  loan  adheres  to  ADB’s  recent  endeavors 
to  adopt  program-based  and  sector  approaches  in  its  lending 
operations to reduce transaction costs for its developing member 
countries  as  well  as  for  its  own  operations.  The  approach  is 
consistent  with  ADB’s  reform  agenda;  Long-Term  Strategic 
Framework,  and  Medium-Term  Strategy,  and  will  directly  help 
fulfill  ADB’s  obligations  to  the  Rome  Declaration  on  harmonizing 
procedures of multilateral development banks. 
 

The main goal of the program loan is to help reduce poverty and 
sustain high-level economic growth, as envisaged in the CPRGS. 
The  purpose  is  to  provide  support  for  implementation  of  the 
Government’s  Poverty  Reduction  Program  within  the  policy 
framework  of  the  PRSC  III,  focusing  on  reducing  structural 
weaknesses  and  improving  business  environment  for  private 
sector  development,  promoting  socially  inclusive  development, 
and modernizing governance.

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

Development Objectives, Strategies, and Plans 

 The  Government  of  Viet  Nam  believes  that  poverty  reduction  is  the  basic  element  in 
2. 
ensuring social justice and sustainable growth, and that high and sustainable growth could bring 
about  the  physical  energy  to  support  and  provide  opportunities  for  the  poor.  The  Government 
therefore  places  poverty  reduction  as  an  overarching  objective  in  its  national  socioeconomic 
development process. To reaffirm its commitment to poverty reduction, the Government signed 
a  poverty  reduction  partnership  agreement  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  2002. 
The Government also has committed to achieving the Millennium Development Goals. 
 
A. 
 
3. 
The  CPRGS  reflects  the  Government’s  commitment  to  inclusive  economic  and  social 
development.  It  elaborates  all  general  objectives,  institutional  arrangements,  policies,  and 
programs  of  the  10-year  Socioeconomic  Development  Strategy  (2001–2010)  and  5-year 
Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (2001–2005)  with  detailed  specific  action  plans.  Unlike 
previous  development  plans,  which followed  a  command  approach  to  economic  management, 
the  CPRGS  is  based  on  empirical  analysis  and  broad  consultation.  It  spells  out  clear 
development goals, identifies the policies to attain them, aligns resources to those policies, and 
establishes  an  appropriate  monitoring  and  evaluation  system.  In  2003,  the  CPRGS  was 
expanded  to  address  issues  related  to  large-scale  infrastructure  and  poverty  reduction.  The 
three  main  pillars  of  the  CPRGS  are  (i)  completing  the  transition  to  a  market  economy,  (ii) 
keeping  development  inclusive  and  sustainable,  and  (iii)  building  modern  governance.  These 
are  consistent  with  ADB’s  poverty  reduction  strategy1—pro-poor  growth,  social  development 
and  good  governance;  and  its  country  strategy  and  program  (2002–2004)2  and  poverty 
partnership  agreement  with  Viet  Nam.3  The  CPRGS  is  widely  recognized  as  a  blueprint  for 
development with strong national ownership. The CPRGS approach will be mainstreamed into 
the  next  5-year  development  plan,  to  be  issued  in  2006.  Details  on  the  CPRGS  are  given  in 
Appendix 2.

Progress with Reducing Poverty 

5. 
The  last  decade  was  characterized  by  substantial  progress  in  the  lives  of  the 
Vietnamese population. Viet Nam halved poverty in about 10 years. The number of people living 
in poverty decreased from 58% in 1993 to 37% in 1998 and to 29% in 2002. Social indicators 
improved markedly, indicating Viet Nam is well-positioned to attain key Millennium Development 
Goals.  Poverty  reduction  has  always  been  underpinned  by  reasonably  rapid,  stable,  and 
inclusive economic growth. A recent joint poverty assessment study indicates that the elasticity 
of poverty reduction has been higher than one, e.g., a growth rate of per capita output of about 
6%  was  associated  with  reduction  in  poverty  of  about  7%.  However,  the  rate  of  poverty 
reduction has slowed in recent years (2 percentage points) from that of the first half of the last 
decade (4 percentage points).5 Poverty reduction is slow or unchanged in northern mountains, 
central highlands, and in pockets of the Red River and Mekong deltas, contributing to regional 
income disparity. Poverty incidence is perpetual and chronic in cross-border areas.

Issues relate to social inclusion and environmental sustainability, particularly education,

adopted under the PRSC II. Measures adopted over the last year hinge on the combination of

In parallel, national minimum standards for primary schools were adopted. A survey covering all 
districts has been launched to assess the current situation relative to the standards, which refer 
to  physical  infrastructure,  teaching  staff,  school  organization  and  management,  social 
participation  in  education,  educational  activities  and  quality,  and  expected  educational 
outcomes.

80. 
Policy  reform  actions  will  improve  transparency  and  accountability  in  SOE  operations 
and  in  the  banking  subsector.  The  establishment  of  a  sound  regulatory  framework  for  policy 
resulting  in  increased  private  investment  and  exports  will  lead  to  additional  job  creation.  The 
program  loan  will  promote  human  development  by  improving  access  by  poor  people  to 
education and health care, and increasing the security of asset ownership in the form of a new 
land law. The policy reform under the PRSC III will increase transparency and accountability of 
public finances and improve legal transparency and accessibility, by laying the foundations for a 
state  ruled  by  law,  and  by  addressing  a  number  of  gaps  in  the  Budget  Law.  Further 
decentralization  of  public  administration  leading  to  better  service  delivery  to  the  poor  and 
increased  local  beneficiary  participation  are  other  expected  benefits.  Development  outcomes 
are summarized in Appendix 8. 
   
81. 
Through  appropriate  measures  and  proactive  programs,  the  Government  will  need  to 
mitigate the potential adverse economic, social, and environmental impacts of increasing trade 
openness, reducing the number of state enterprises, and liberalizing land transactions.  
 
82. 
Incomplete  structural  reform  could  jeopardize  growth  and  stability  in  the  longer  term. 
Haphazard  introduction  of  market  forces  in  the  social  sectors,  and  the  trend  toward 
decentralization  have  put  service  delivery  under  strain.  At  the  same  time,  fast  integration  with 
the world economy may lead to increased inequality, at least temporarily, as the benefits accrue 
to specific regions and skills disproportionately. Growth in Viet Nam could become less inclusive 
in the years to come.

transparency and tackling corruption is inadequate. The Government is indicating new resolve 
to  address  these  issues.  It  has  recently  embarked  on  revamping  its  anticorruption  strategy.  It 
has also enhanced budget transparency. Their full implementation will be crucial to mitigate the 
fiduciary risk.

Formulation  of  policy  reforms  and  programs  under  the  CPRGS  involves  many  ministries

A comprehensive poverty analysis was jointly carried out as background to the preparation of the PRSC III1. Viet 
Nam’s achievements in terms of social development and poverty reduction have been remarkable. Almost one third of 
total population was lifted out of poverty in less then 10 years. Poverty incidence was halved during 1993–2002. 
Economic growth underpinned the rapid poverty reduction. The elasticity of poverty reduction to economic growth was 
higher than one. 
 
The decline in poverty was widespread as the increase in inequality has been modest so far. Social indicators 
improved markedly, positioning Viet Nam well to attain key Millennium Development Goals. The last decade was thus 
characterized by undeniable progress in the lives of the Vietnamese population.

rich and poor regions, because rich regions have higher local resources and revenues, and thus will be able to spend

poor in these regions. Targeted programs, such as Program 135, are in place and have generally benefited the poor.  
 
To further reduce poverty and sustain the high level of economic growth, Viet Nam needs to remove structural 
weaknesses, promote socially and environmentally inclusive development, and modernize governance and the public

The program loan will contribute to the continuation of Viet Nam’s economic growth in a pro-poor fashion; its 
implementation will have a significant positive impact on poverty reduction and social services delivery in an

The program loan will support the provision of reforms and policies that will stimulate and promote sustainable, 
equitable growth, as stipulated in the PRSC III documents, on three main fronts. First, it will promote growth and 
create employment through greater internal and external competition, accelerate the divestiture of SOEs and

and in the financial sector. Second, it will advance human development and economic growth through; an expanded 
budget appropriation and higher quality standards for education; resources to cover the health care costs of the 
poor; mechanisms to complete the transfer of land-use rights to households, more secure asset ownership in the 
form of a new land law especially in upland and ethnic minority areas; and measures to improve environmental and 
water resources management. Third, the program loan will increase transparency and accountability of public 
finances; promote simplified administrative procedures; reduce corruption, and revamp the planning processes as

The reforms will result in increased private investment and exports, which will lead to additional job creation. Further 
decentralization of public administration leading to better service delivery to the poor and increased local beneficiary 
participation are other expected benefits. Through appropriate measures and proactive programs, the Government 
will need to mitigate the potential adverse economic, social, and environmental impacts of increased trade 
openness, reduction in state enterprises, and liberalization in land transactions.  
 
Strong direct and indirect benefits are expected to reach the poor in terms of increased and more rewarding 
employment opportunities, improved service delivery, decentralized planning, and promotion of beneficiary 
participation. Any increase in employment opportunity and efficiency gain in service delivery will directly benefit the 
poor. The Government has special programs and policies in place to ensure that women and the poor have access 
to jobs, basic health services, education, and infrastructure, especially in the mountainous regions and in poor 
urban areas, and have priority. Its commitment to enhancing the well-being of ethnic minorities is reflected in the 
country’s constitution and the creation in 1983 of the Committee for Ethnic Minorities with ministry status. 
 
Greater exposure to world markets could lead to higher risk/variability in prices and hence the income of wage 
earners and farmers, but its overall impact is likely to be positive for the rural sector. Analytical work is ongoing for 
the coffee sector. Further commercialization of the economy may increase inequality, unless rectifying measures 
are taken early. An assessment of the poverty and social impact of WTO accession is being undertaken, and 
includes a combination of analyses at three levels (a computable general equilibrium model to predict chances in 
prices of goods and services; regional models to determine changes in prices of factors of production that are not 
mobile, such as land and labor; and estimated impact on consumption at the household level). The regions of Hanoi 
and Ho Chi Minh City are expected to benefit most from WTO accession, while the poverty reduction effect for the 
mountainous areas could be more modest.  
 
Restructuring and divesting of SOEs will cause labor retrenchment. To offset the adverse impact of retrenchment, 
the Government has established a fund for retrenched SOE workers. This fund has been in place since mid-2002 
and a recent evaluation rates the fund as highly effective.  
 
Reliance on market forces and private sector involvement in providing basic services could help expand the 
availability of services and create new employment opportunities, but prices of services may go up. To minimize 
such impacts, basic services for low-income groups are provided free of charge or at reduced costs and as part of 
safety nets. These programs already exist but may need to be expanded depending on the scope and pace of 
privatization/cost recovery. Careful consideration must be given to interregional equity when reforming service 
delivery, particularly for health, education, transportation, and communication infrastructure.  
 
Decentralization should make local level government more accountable to the poorest for their participation in 
decision making on development programs and delivery of services. The current participation of the poor in the 
planning and decision-making process is low. Poor households are usually physically remote and socially 
marginalized. The Government has programs in place to accelerate access to social services and education for the 
poor and ethnic minorities in remote areas. 
 
The new land law is expected to benefit poor and vulnerable people. As the land market develops in the medium 
term, the potential adverse social impacts may have to be addressed. Two studies on the potential implications of a 
land market will be undertaken as part of the preparation of PRSC IV. Studies on land markets are also under way 
as part of the ongoing Making Markets Work Better for the Poor project being implemented by ADB.  
 
Incomplete structural reform could jeopardize growth and stability in the longer term. A fiduciary risk is associated 
with inadequate progress on enhancing budget transparency and tackling corruption. Haphazard introduction of 
market forces in the social sectors, and the trend toward decentralization have put service delivery under strain. At 
the same time, fast integration with the world economy may lead to increased inequality, at least temporarily, as the 
benefits accrue to specific regions and skills disproportionately. Growth in Viet Nam could become less inclusive in
